title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions such as the expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor, discharge of agricultural cargo residue, recording and discharging maritime liens, and various certificates of documentation for vessels like the R/V DAVIDSON and the EAGLE. Additionally, it amends Section 1120(g) of the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996 to include the vessel COASTAL VENTURE. The Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996 is amended to include the vessel COASTAL VENTURE (United States official number 971086). Additionally, the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor is expanded. The Congress recognizes the significant contributions of the United States Merchant Marine in various wars, including serving as the Nation's first navy, keeping the lifeline of freedom open during World War II, and being praised as the "Fourth Arm of Defense" by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine during World War II. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role as the "Fourth Arm of Defense," with over 250,000 men and women serving. They faced dangers from submarines, mines, and other threats, resulting in 6,830 deaths and 11,000 wounded members. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine suffered significant casualties, with over 6,830 members killed at sea, 11,000 wounded, and 604 taken prisoner. They had a higher percentage of war-related deaths than any other armed service. Despite these losses, the Merchant Marine continues to serve the United States, upholding the ideals of its former members. Grants are proposed for the construction of an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor. The United States Merchant Marine suffered the highest percentage of war-related deaths during World War II. Grants are proposed for constructing an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. The Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California will receive a 50 percent Federal share for activities, with an authorization of $500,000 for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. Discharge of agricultural cargo residue is governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. Recording and discharging maritime liens. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. The Secretary must record a notice complying with the section if a declaration stating the information is true and correct is filed along with the notice. The Secretary must record a notice complying with subsection (a) if a declaration is filed stating the information is true and correct. This includes sending a copy of the notice to the vessel owner, holders of existing liens, and mortgagees. The declaration must be signed by authorized individuals and filed to discharge a lien on a vessel as per the amended subsection. The amended subsection requires a certificate of discharge of indebtedness to be provided to the Secretary upon full repayment of the lien on a vessel. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions to contest vessel liens, regardless of the amount or parties' citizenship. The amended subsection requires a certificate of discharge of indebtedness to be provided to the Secretary upon full repayment of the lien on a vessel. Civil actions to contest vessel liens can be brought in district courts, with venue determined by where the vessel is located, where the claimant resides, or where the notice of claim of lien is recorded. The court may award costs and attorneys fees to the prevailing party, unless justified otherwise. A notice of claim of lien expires 3 years after recording. This section does not change the law on establishing maritime liens or the remedies available. The notice of claim of lien recorded under subsection (b) expires 3 years after the specified date. This section does not alter the law on maritime liens or remedies available. Section 31325 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to require an unexpired notice of a claim for recording and discharging liens. Additionally, the Secretary cannot refuse to approve surrender of vessel documentation based solely on a recorded lien claim under section 31343(a) of this title. The Secretary cannot deny approval for surrendering vessel documentation solely due to a recorded lien claim. The surrender may be conditioned for vessels over 1,000 gross tons. A technical correction is made to the Shipping Act, 1916. This section will be effective from July 1, 2002. SEC. 7. Tonnage of R/V DAVIDSON: The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the vessel R/V DAVIDSON as a small passenger vessel for regulatory purposes. This applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. SEC. 8. Miscellaneous Certificates of Documentation. The Secretary of Transportation can issue certificates of documentation for specific vessels for coastwise trade, bypassing certain regulations. Vessels include LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, and VICTORY OF BURNHAM. The vessels listed for coastwise trade include ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, SKIMMER, TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, and AJ. The vessels listed in the curr_chunk include TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO. SEC. 9 amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, US Code to exempt SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10 deals with the certificate of documentation for 3 barges. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in coastwise trade for specific vessels, including former Navy and railroad car barges with certain dimensions. These vessels are limited to use as floating. The former railroad car barges HUGH and TOMMY have lengths of 185 feet and widths of 34 feet. Vessels issued a certificate of documentation under this section are limited to being used as floating platforms for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR THE EAGLE. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for employment in the coastwise trade under specific conditions. A vessel must be operated in conjunction with scour jet operations or dredging services adjacent to state-owned facilities to be eligible for a certificate of documentation in the coastwise trade. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Beginning April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the race can transport guests without payment until race completion or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER may be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
